Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Welcome Rob: I concur with "Another" that you are VERY fortunate to have discovered this diagnosis at age 44. Since the other forum brothers have addressed the primary issues (as in focus on mortality rather than erections), I note that you have spoken only about "open" radical prostatectomy. Is that because where you reside there is no facility with a robotic option available? Open surgery was the gold standard for prostatectomies for decades but with the advent of the DaVinci robotic method, there is less potential for complications and blood loss and a quicker, less painful path to full recovery. If given the surgical choice, I would always opt for the robotic mode. On the radiation side, Cyberknife may sound like a "quick fix" but if you do a search of patient satisfaction surveys following PC treatment, Cyberknife is nearly always at the bottom of the listings as the massive doses of radiation sometimes leave patients with painful burns through the rectal area that may last for years (I personally know two such patients). A Gleason 6 diagnosis may lead many to a sense of relief but the high degree of involvement of the cores and the observation of capsular abutment causes me to agree with Pratoman that something more potent may be lurking. Best of luck, Jim No, I live in central southern Virginia, and I am about 1 hr. 45 min. drive from Duke Cancer Center. They have another surgeon that does the Robotic method, but I have spoken to the one so far. He claims that it is a shorter procedure and that it can be preformed just as effective as the Robotic method. It's about a 4 inch incision above the pubic bone. "Minimally Invasive Small Incision Retropubic Prostatectomy"
Posts.Signature: - Age at Diagnosis: 44 - 3/2016 - PSA 1.0 - Urologist during DRE found nodule on the right side of the prostate, 9/2016 - Biopsy performed on 10/19/2016, Diagnosis -T2bN0M0 - Gleason 6(3+3) - Adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (3+ 3) involving 2 cores from the right mid gland, 80% and 40% involvement respectively. 3 cores involved from the right base, with a Gleason score of 6 (3+ 3) involving 60%, 50%, and 50% of these cores respectively - 11/16/2016 - PSA 0.77 - MRI 1/6/2017 - Oncologist Recommended RP 1/12/2017 - Consult with Surgeon - RP , Open Method 3/9/2017
Posts.Title: Struggling with course of treatment decision?

Posts.Content: Just recently been diagnosed back in October, and all recommendations so far have been for Surgery. I know this seems like the logical choice to make, but at this time I am really struggling with that decision mainly because of the sexual side effects that come with this course of treatment. With me being only 44 and my wife being 34, this really scares the hell out of me if you know what I mean! I have been reading a lot recently into the Cyberknife (SBRT) method, but its hard for me to find any good recent data. There's also so many mixed reviews out there, its hard to know what to believe. Just had a consult with surgeon (Duke) last week (open Method), he's done thousands of this procedure. MRI showed.......... The prostate gland measures: 4.3 x 2.7 x 3.7 cm. Volume 19.4 mL. Peripheral zone: Observation 1: Within the right peripheral zone at the base, there is a 1.0 x 0.6 cm of T2 hypointensity and restricted diffusion. This shows approximately 1.0 cm of capsular abutment. Central gland: No index lesion. Prostatic capsule: Observation 1 abuts the prostatic capsule for approximately 1 cm. Neurovascular bundles: Capsular abutment is in the region of the right neurovascular bundle. Seminal vesicles: Normal. Lymph nodes: No lymphadenopathy. Bones: No aggressive bone lesions. Impression: Observation 1 in the peripheral zone of the right base measures 1.0 x 0.6 cm and shows approximately 1 cm of capsular abutment in the region of the right neurovascular bundle. PI-RADS 4. "
Posts.Signature: - Age at Diagnosis: 44 - 3/2016 - PSA 1.0 - Urologist during DRE found nodule on the right side of the prostate, 9/2016 - Biopsy performed on 10/19/2016, Diagnosis -T2bN0M0 - Gleason 6(3+3) - Adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (3+ 3) involving 2 cores from the right mid gland, 80% and 40% involvement respectively. 3 cores involved from the right base, with a Gleason score of 6 (3+ 3) involving 60%, 50%, and 50% of these cores respectively - 11/16/2016 - PSA 0.77 - MRI 1/6/2017 - Oncologist Recommended RP 1/12/2017 - Consult with Surgeon - RP , Open Method 3/9/2017
Posts.Title: Struggling with course of treatment decision?

Posts.Content: I am curious how you discovered this so early without symptoms or family history. It is unusual to be testing PSA so early. You are very lucky! [/QUOTE] I did have symptoms, I went to see my Urologist when I stared having trouble emptying my bladder completely, and was having some mild ED issues. During the DRE he found what he called a nodule/bump. He then suggested that it might be Prostatitis, so he prescribed me a couple of courses of antibiotics, and when it didn't go away he decided to do the biopsy. I still cant get a good answer/reason on as to why my PSA is so low. It's even went down since the biopsy......0.7!
